pineconeReadyTickets.summary: [SPIKE] AFS Tool to generate Shop rate lift calculations

content.text: Provide per campaign Shop Rate Lift (SRL)in Dashboard helps customers know their campaign are working.
We need to first learn how to provide Shop Rate Lift via this article:
The goals of this spike are to answer these questions:
1Ô∏è‚É£   Can we retrieve the Shop Rate Lift via the article below?
2Ô∏è‚É£   Can we create one script that takes into an array of campaign_ids and produces the shop rate lift for each campaign that is still ongoing?
3Ô∏è‚É£   Can a job be setup to take from an s3 csv file campaign_ids and run a script(above) to then store the shop rate lift for each campaign?

4Ô∏è‚É£  THIS POINT IS OPTIONAL FOR NOW ----> Given that the dashboard would like to have this SRL shown for campaigns, how would we store this value in our database? A table campaign_afs_shop_rate_list_value<id, cid, dateFrom, dateTo, srl_value>?
1Ô∏è‚É£  Existing Confluence documentation (see above) and here as well (my Confluence
1Ô∏è‚É£  Confluence report answering the questions above.
1Ô∏è‚É£  A solid plan is created and documented in Confluence with enough details for newer team members (to AFS) that they can follow well.
Concerns: Tool, Need to improve requirements.
1Ô∏è‚É£ Business picks campaigns to have AFS shop rate lift shown in the Dashboard campaign page
2Ô∏è‚É£ Business creates PROD Jira ticket listing campaign links that must be active campaigns
3Ô∏è‚É£ For each campaign link in PROD ticket, DE creates a consolidated log file
4Ô∏è‚É£ DE Uploads consolidated log files (one for each campaign) to AFS S3 bucket (logs as before, same format of IP & timestamp)
5Ô∏è‚É£ DE creates a job via AFS API to create a weekly report that runs every Tuesday at 8am until campaigns ends
6Ô∏è‚É£  It‚Äôs useful to hit {{baseUrl}}/v3/datafeed/refreshStatus and ensure that the
date < today prior to running reports.
7Ô∏è‚É£ The dataset created by the report is ingested appropriately for Dashboard‚Äôs consumption.

attrs.title: The manual way to get this Shop Rate Lift number...

content.text: 'Per campaign' reporting in DASH. Consolidated reporting done manually & not available in DASH for now.

For example, Royal Farms run 21 campaigns, hence there are 21 campaign pages in DASH. Each campaign page will have one reporting widget that display the shop rate lift produced by the given campaign only.
Consolidated reporting (the cumulative lift produced by all the campaigns) to be done manually.
There will be no automated way for business/AM to kick off AFS measurements 'by a click of a button'. Suggested workflow:
Business decides to what campaigns they want include in AFS measurements, they create a ticket in the PROD Jira, and list campaign links. The campaigns should be active.
DE creates a job that consolidates all impression logs of the given campaigns into a single file.
DE creates a job that uploads individual campaigns' impression logs and the consolidated impression log to the AFS S3 bucket
Individual campaign logs should include the dates from {campaign start} to {yesterday 23:59:59}
Consolidate campaign log should include the dates {the earliest campaign start} to {yesterday 23:59:59}
Note: it‚Äôs useful to hit {{baseUrl}}/v3/datafeed/refreshStatus and ensure that the
date < today prior to running reports.
Each new report run should create a fresh dataset for DASH to visualise.
Once the job is set up, it should run automatically every Tue at 8am PT until campaigns reach end on life (current date > campaign end date).
DE will have an SLA for this initial setup (something like 2-5 business days looks reasonable)
Once the data is uploaded, another job should run reporting following this algorithm
The resulting report should look like
AFS brand_id from their datafeed_brands report
Our field report end date = impression log cut-off date¬†
No other metrics but the shop rate lift in the reporting
No breakout (shop rate by geo, demo, tactic)
Native visualisation in DASH or embed quicksight widgets? -
If native, the resulting data should be in the
table. If quicksight, then a separate S3 bucket.

pineconeReadyTickets.summary: [EC][SPIKE] Investigate End Date Mismatches Between ZD Notes and PIO Change Logs

content.text: During e2e testing of the Edit Campaign project, an issue with updating the end-date was identified:
Saransh Mishra's notes are described here:

According to our process, EC (Edit Campaign) sends a request to OA (OrderAPI). Dates are sent including time zones, but the time zone value is not explicitly specified. OrderAPI then sends a request to PIO (only with
Because of this, it is unclear at which step the discrepancy is introduced (whether it's on the EC side, OA side, or in PIO).
Investigate the full flow for start-date, end-date changes across EC, OA, and PIO.
Identify where the mismatch is introduced.
Provide recommendations for resolving or improving date/time zone handling.

content.text: As our AI project continues to grow in complexity, developers are increasingly at risk of introducing errors or vulnerabilities without automated checks in place. Currently, the absence of autotesting means potential issues are detected too late, often requiring costly manual reviews or fixes after merging. To resolve this, we should set up SonarQube as our primary tool for automated testing, starting with establishing a dashboard-based setup and integrating it into our GitHub Actions workflows. This will prevent merging problematic code by automatically detecting issues early and improving overall code quality and reliability.

Implementing SonarQube integration will significantly reduce manual code reviews, prevent regressions and vulnerabilities from reaching production, and ensure higher-quality, maintainable code, thus increasing team efficiency and confidence in project stability.

Suppress Incomplete RAG Outputs via Relevance Thresholding

content.text: Our end-users who rely on our system for answering complex queries that span both statistical data and knowledge-based content are currently facing inconsistent results. While the statistical module consistently provides accurate outputs, the Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) component often fails to deliver relevant answers when the retrieval phase misses critical documents. This leads to situations where the RAG system either gives incomplete information or defaults to a fallback message ("I don't have an answer"), which negatively affects user trust and perceived system reliability. To resolve this, we propose introducing a reranking step within the retrieval pipeline that uses a model to reorder documents based on relevance. By applying a minimum quality threshold, the system can determine whether the RAG response should be generated at all, thus ensuring that responses are only attempted when context quality is sufficient.

Implementing reranking and introducing a quality gate in the RAG pipeline will significantly improve the precision and consistency of knowledge-based responses. This enhancement will lead to better user trust, improved end-to-end system performance, and a more professional user experience, especially in mixed-domain queries where partial answers currently degrade the overall system output.
Add a reranking step to the RAG retrieval pipeline using a relevance-scoring model.
Configure the reranker to score the top N documents and reorder them based on relevance to the input query.
Define a configurable quality threshold score that determines if the top-ranked documents are sufficient to proceed with RAG generation.
If the score falls below the threshold, suppress the RAG output and optionally return a more informative fallback message.
Ensure the statistical component remains unaffected and continues to respond independently when applicable.

To enhance our analysis and improve the overall effectiveness of our marketing strategies, it is essential to push for access to Tier 2 industry classifications. By addressing this issue, we can ensure that our models reflect a more accurate representation of the market, ultimately leading to better decision-making and improved campaign performance.
Implementing this change will significantly enhance the accuracy of our marketing models, allowing the team to make more informed decisions based on reliable data.
Obtain access to Tier 2 industry classifications.
Update the existing industry mapping to include the new classifications.

pineconeReadyTickets.summary: [Spike] Initial NLQ Model Evaluation Framework for AI Team

content.text: The AI team is preparing to evaluate large language models (LLMs) for Natural Language Query (NLQ) tasks for the first time. As more advanced models continue to emerge, it is important to establish a consistent and repeatable framework for comparison. Without such a structure, future evaluations would require starting from scratch each time, leading to delays and potential inconsistencies. This task will kick off the process by comparing our current Llama 3.2 70B model with several newer alternatives. The goal is to not only identify the most suitable model for our immediate needs but also to define and document a reliable evaluation approach that can be reused going forward.

Implementing this comparison and evaluation framework will enable the AI team to efficiently assess future LLMs as they become available. It ensures informed decision-making for model selection, improves transparency, and saves time in future iterations.

To resolve this issue, we need to implement a system that logs the accuracy scores and relevant metadata of each model upon deployment, allowing for better evaluation and selection of models based on their performance.

This restriction stems from a concern that the chatbot might expose sensitive financial numbers, such as values not including markups. However, our system already stores accurate and client-safe pricing information (e.g., retail prices) used for invoicing. To resolve this, we should enhance our platform to allow the chatbot to display these verified financial values in campaign summaries.

Enabling the chatbot to display safe financial figures like total spend and budget will empower internal teams with better visibility into campaign performance, streamline reporting, and reduce the need for manual data retrieval. This will also help establish greater trust in the chatbot as a reliable tool for operational support.

This will help us prevent faulty releases and respond more quickly when problems arise.

Enhancing our observability and monitoring capabilities will reduce downtime, enable faster incident response, and help maintain trust in our platform. It will also support smoother deployment cycles and give developers confidence that issues will be detected early and accurately.

pineconeReadyTickets.summary: Remove IAM Users from Compulse AWS Account
Design and Plan Permissions Matrix for AWS and RDS Access by Team

content.text: Currently, there is no structured segregation of permissions across our infrastructure. All users, regardless of their role, are granted full admin access in AWS, and similarly, there is no clear distinction between user access levels in our RDS databases.

This is a security concern ‚Äî especially since we store secrets in AWS Secrets Manager and sensitive data in RDS. Without proper access control, any user can potentially view or modify data across environments.
This ticket aims to initiate a planning phase to define a
for both AWS and RDS access, ensuring each team (QA, Dev, Prod, etc.) only has the necessary privileges based on their responsibilities.
Audit and document all current users with access to AWS and RDS.
Group users by team or environment (QA, Dev, Prod, etc.).
Define a clear permissions matrix for:
Identify common access patterns and dependencies per team.
Review and validate the plan with upper management.
Prepare a roadmap for implementation, to be broken down into follow-up tickets.
A complete list of all users with access to AWS and RDS.
Users are categorized by team or function.
A detailed and documented permissions matrix is created for AWS and RDS.
Examples of access needs per team are included (e.g., Dev needs write access to dev RDS, read-only access to prod).
The proposal is reviewed and approved by upper management.
A set of execution tickets is created for the implementation phase

pineconeReadyTickets.summary: Wiz Issue: Publicly readable bucket (allows direct anonymous read access)

content.text: : This bucket/blob container/storage account has an overly permissive policy allowing anonymous read access ("*").

In order to access the relevant resource, an attacker simply needs to be familiar with its name, which is public information. It could be configured to allow unauthenticated access, or limit access to any user of the relevant cloud service provider (but since anyone can sign up for free, this is equivalent to unauthenticated access).

Publicly exposed resources are more easily accessible for an attacker than internal ones. Therefore, a publicly exposed bucket can be more easily compromised by an attacker. Any attacker familiar with the bucket's endpoint can exfiltrate whatever data it contains.
Source Automation Rule: Zypmedia Create Ticket Rule for Jira

[Platform | CG] FE Spike: Evaluate and Implement E2E Testing Strategy for React and Vue Projects

content.text: We have two UI projects ‚Äî one built with React.js (portal) and another with Vue.js (cg) ‚Äî that currently lack E2E (end-to-end) test coverage. The goal of this spike is to:
Evaluate and decide on the best E2E testing framework suited for both projects.
Create one simple test case for each project (e.g., load and verify homepage).
Set up browserless test execution in our GitHub Actions CI/CD pipeline (or raise a DevOps ticket if infra support is needed).
Tests should be able to run on
Tests should be lightweight and able to run in
Developer-friendly, strong Vue/React support, good docs, CI-ready
A decision is made between Cypress, Playwright, Selenium, or any other suitable framework based on comparison (maintainability, CI support, cross-framework compatibility).
Please contact the other team devs after the first research.
A minimal E2E test is written for:
React project (e.g., load homepage and assert text exists)
Vue project (e.g., load homepage and assert text exists)
The test is executed headlessly using browserless mode in GitHub Actions pipeline.
If infra changes are needed, a separate DevOps ticket is raised with clear steps and dependencies.
Spike summary with findings and recommendations is documented and shared with the team.
GitHub Actions Workflow Example For Cypress:

name: E2E Tests

on:
  push:
    branches: [main]
  pull_request:
    branches: [main]

jobs:
  e2e-tests:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    strategy:
      matrix:
        project: [react-ui, vue-ui]

    steps:
      - name: Checkout Code
        uses: actions/checkout@v3

      - name: Setup Node
        uses: actions/setup-node@v3
        with:
          node-version: '18'

      - name: Install Dependencies
        run: |
          cd ${{ matrix.project }}
          npm ci

      - name: Build Project
        run: |
          cd ${{ matrix.project }}
          npm run build

      - name: Start App (Preview/Prod URL)
        run: echo "Skipping local app launch ‚Äì test will hit live environment URL"

      - name: Run Cypress Tests (headless)
        uses: cypress-io/github-action@v6
        with:
          working-directory: ${{ matrix.project }}
          browser: chrome
          headless: true
          config: baseUrl=https://your-preview-or-staging-url.com

      - name: Upload Cypress Artifacts on Failure
        if: failure()
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
        with:
          name: cypress-screenshots
          path: ${{ matrix.project }}/cypress/screenshots
GitHub Actions Workflow Example For Playwright E2E on Browserless Mode

name: Playwright E2E Tests

on:
  push:
    branches: [main]
  pull_request:
    branches: [main]

jobs:
  e2e-tests:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    strategy:
      matrix:
        project: [react-ui, vue-ui]

    steps:
      - name: Checkout Code
        uses: actions/checkout@v3

      - name: Setup Node
        uses: actions/setup-node@v3
        with:
          node-version: '18'

      - name: Install Dependencies
        run: |
          cd ${{ matrix.project }}
          npm ci

      - name: Install Playwright Browsers
        run: |
          cd ${{ matrix.project }}
          npx playwright install --with-deps

      - name: Run Playwright Tests
        run: |
          cd ${{ matrix.project }}
          npx playwright test --project=chromium
        env:
          BASE_URL: https://your-preview-or-staging-url.com

      - name: Upload Test Results on Failure
        if: failure()
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
        with:
          name: playwright-report
          path: ${{ matrix.project }}/playwright-report/

The new view will be presented to the user upon signing in to Analytics. Currently, we show the ‚ÄúPost-Login Landing Page‚Äù. At this page, we want to provide the user the option to see the new view/page.
Here‚Äôs an example of what Ryan Siska mocked up:

We want to keep the current ‚ÄúPost-Login Landing Page‚Äù, but give the user an option to go to the new view/page. Use a tabbed approach or another approach. Once the user has selected the new view/page, then next time they return to this page, this same view will appear, so that they don‚Äôt have to switch views every time they return to this page.

At the next level, show each Advertiser with a summary of its Campaigns, Pacing, and Performance.
At the next level, make each advertiser expandable/collapsible to show the products that have campaigns. Show a summary of its Campaigns, Pacing, and Performance.
Then, at the next level, show the list of campaigns under that product. At this level, we only need to show the summary of its Pacing and Performance, since Campaigns would not apply here.

Give user the option to show campaigns at the top level, regardless of advertiser, so that the campaigns that need attention are sorted to the top without having to drill down by agency, then by advertiser, then by product.
Provide sort options for the Pacing and the Performance metrics.
The user will have a button that they click on to get to Resources that have definitions and thresholds information.
The user will have a button that they click on to get to Help or Support applicable to them. So, for Sinclair, it‚Äôll be one place, but for Enterprise, it‚Äôd be a different place.

[FE] YouTube - Update tooltip in "Campaign Summary" module for "VCR"

content.text: Currently, the explanation for ‚ÄúVCR‚Äù in the ‚ÄúCampaign Summary‚Äù module for YouTube campaigns is confusing/misleading.

Percentage of campaign impressions that are viewed to completion. If 10 impressions are served and 9 are viewed to completion, VCR is 90%. A campaign is not likely ever going to reach 100%. A VCR of at least 90% is good.

Percentage of campaign views that are viewed to completion (‚Äú100% Viewed‚Äù divided by ‚ÄúViews‚Äù). If 10 views are served and 9 are viewed to completion, VCR is 90%. A VCR of at least 90% is good.
